newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: RUGBY UNION - Samoans score fine victory over Irish.
newsitem.headline: RUGBY UNION - Samoans score fine victory over Irish.

text.p: DUBLIN, Nov 12 - Western Samoa turned on a sparkling five-try display to deservedly beat Ireland 40-25 in their rugby test at Lansdowne Road, NZPA reported on Wednesday (NZT).
The win in Western Samoa's only test of this British tour represents one of the Pacific Islanders' finest international results.
Western Samoa were in a dominating mood from the time lock Potu Leavasa barged into Irish winger Richard Wallace during the pre-match "Manu Samoa" challenge until the final whistle.
They scored three tries to lead 25-12 at halftime and continued to control play in the second spell, defending doggedly as Ireland desperately tried to cross their line.
The Irish finally managed it in the 71st minute, prop Paul Wallace being driven over, but that was their only moment of glory in front of their own crowd.
Western Samoa's reply to the challenge was, as always, to score again at the other end.
The reply to Wallace's try came through centre To'o Vaega, who glided through the defence to score his second try of the match.
Fullback Veli Patu had scored the first try of the second half, winning the race to his chip-kick and touching down on the left flank.
First five-eight Earl Va'a, on his test debut, kicked three conversions and three penalties for a personal tally of 15 points.
Ireland's main contributor was fullback Simon Mason who kicked six penalties and a conversion, but he also missed four attempts at goal.
Western Samoa 40 (To'o Vaega 2, Veli Patu, Afato So'oalo, George Leaupepe tries; Earl Va'a 3 pen, 3 con).
Ireland 25 (Paul Wallace try; Simon Mason six pen, 1 con). Halftime 25-12.
